paragraphs.text:
%md
# Basic Classes

Classes are the fundamental element of object-oriented programming (OOP). Normally this is in contrast to functional programming, but Scala supports and integrates both approaches (functional and object oriented programming) very well.

The basic idea of a class is to provide a template for constructing similar object which encapsulate some state and provide operations to modify the state. Commonly *operations* are called *methods* and these are only available for instances of the specific class. Formally *modifying* state is strongly against functional idioms, but modern approaches follow a middle way, where instances of classes are immutable and any modification actually creates a new instance. We already saw this concept with immutable collection classes.

result.msg:
Basic Classes

Classes are the fundamental element of object-oriented programming (OOP). Normally this is in contrast to functional programming, but Scala supports and integrates both approaches (functional and object oriented programming) very well.

The basic idea of a class is to provide a template for constructing similar object which encapsulate some state and provide operations to modify the state. Commonly operations are called methods and these are only available for instances of the specific class. Formally modifying state is strongly against functional idioms, but modern approaches follow a middle way, where instances of classes are immutable and any modification actually creates a new instance. We already saw this concept with immutable collection classes.

paragraphs.text:
%md
# 1 Simple Classes

The following example creates a simple class representing some point in a two-dimensional space. It contains two so called methods `move` and `toString`.

result.msg:
1 Simple Classes

The following example creates a simple class representing some point in a two-dimensional space. It contains two so called methods move and toString.
defined class Point

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 1.1 Creating class instances

Since Scala is 'just' another language on the JVM, it also uses `new` to create a new instance of a class. We'll see some syntactic sugar later on, but eventually `new` is always used to create an instance.

result.msg:
1.1 Creating class instances

Since Scala is ‘just’ another language on the JVM, it also uses new to create a new instance of a class. We’ll see some syntactic sugar later on, but eventually new is always used to create an instance.

paragraphs.text:
// Create an instance of a point at location 3,4.
val p1 = new Point(3,4)

result.msg: p1: Point = [x=3,y=4]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 1.2 Calling methods

Calling mathods works completely the same as we are used in Java. Although in certain cases you can omit the paranthese.

result.msg:
1.2 Calling methods

Calling mathods works completely the same as we are used in Java. Although in certain cases you can omit the paranthese.

paragraphs.text:
// Use the move method to create a new Point that is at a slightly different coordinate
val p2 = p1.move(2,1)

result.msg: p2: Point = [x=5,y=5]

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 1.3 Accessing variables

Surprisingly although `x` and `y` can be accessed in any method of the class, they are not member variables. Therefore they cannot be accessed outside of the class.

result.msg:
1.3 Accessing variables

Surprisingly although x and y can be accessed in any method of the class, they are not member variables. Therefore they cannot be accessed outside of the class.

paragraphs.text: p1.x

result.msg:
<console>:29: error: value x is not a member of Point
       p1.x
          ^

paragraphs.text:
%md
But we can define `x` and `y` as member variables, simply by prepending a `val` in front of them:

result.msg: But we can define x and y as member variables, simply by prepending a val in front of them:

defined class Point

p1: Point = [x=3,y=4]

res9: Int = 3

paragraphs.text:
%md
# 2 Deriving Classes

New functionality can be added to a class by *subclassing*. This will create a *derived* class which inherits all methods and fields from the *base class*, but can add or change functionality. The base class is specified using the `extends` keyword. Note that it also has to receive all required arguments for its constructor. Most of the time the derived class simply will have the same parameters or some additional ones, so the parameters can simply be passed to the base class.

result.msg:
2 Deriving Classes

New functionality can be added to a class by subclassing. This will create a derived class which inherits all methods and fields from the base class, but can add or change functionality. The base class is specified using the extends keyword. Note that it also has to receive all required arguments for its constructor. Most of the time the derived class simply will have the same parameters or some additional ones, so the parameters can simply be passed to the base class.

defined class Location

l1: Location = [x=3,y=4,name=Home]

l2: Location = [x=8,y=13,name=Home]

paragraphs.text: l1.x

result.msg: res10: Int = 3

paragraphs.text:
%md
# 3 Traits (similar to Interfaces)

Each class can have only a single base class - this is an intended limitation of the JVM. Nevertheless a class can also inherit from so called *traits* (which are equivalent to *interfaces* in Java or other OOP programming languages.). A trait is very similar to a class, but cannot be instantiated. Instead soem class has to extend the trait and implement all methods and fields.

result.msg:
3 Traits (similar to Interfaces)

Each class can have only a single base class - this is an intended limitation of the JVM. Nevertheless a class can also inherit from so called traits (which are equivalent to interfaces in Java or other OOP programming languages.). A trait is very similar to a class, but cannot be instantiated. Instead soem class has to extend the trait and implement all methods and fields.
defined trait Addressable

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 3.1 Implementing a trait

A trait is always added to a class via the `with` keyword.

result.msg:
3.1 Implementing a trait

A trait is always added to a class via the with keyword.

paragraphs.text:
class Person(val name:String, val age:Int) extends Object with Addressable {
    override var city:String = ""
    override var street:String = ""
}

val p1 = new Person("Alice", 23)
p1.city = "Frankfurt"
p1.street = "Mainzer Landstraße 21"
p1.getAddress

%md
# 4 Companion Object

Scala does not directly provide *static methds*, i.e. methods of a class which can be invoked without an instance of the class. Instead Scala provides obejcts and specifically *companion objects* which have the same name as a class. Companion objects and classes have some intimid relation (which does not work completely in Zeppelin or other Scala REPLs).

result.msg:
4 Companion Object

Scala does not directly provide static methds, i.e. methods of a class which can be invoked without an instance of the class. Instead Scala provides obejcts and specifically companion objects which have the same name as a class. Companion objects and classes have some intimid relation (which does not work completely in Zeppelin or other Scala REPLs).

paragraphs.text:
%md
## 4.1 Calling an object method

Methods of Scala objects behave like static methods of Java classes.

result.msg:
4.1 Calling an object method

Methods of Scala objects behave like static methods of Java classes.

paragraphs.text:
// A method can be called from Location without having an instance
val loc = Location.create(12,13,"Home")

%md
## 4.2 Calling the `apply` method

result.msg: 4.2 Calling the apply method

paragraphs.text:
// Using the Location object as a function will invoke the "apply" method of the object. This is often used as an alternative way for constructing class instances without the "new" keyword
val loc = Location(12,13,"Home")

%md
# 5 Case Classes

In addition to classes and (companion) objects, Scala also provides so called *case classes*. These are special *value* classes which automatically provide lots of functionality. They are very useful for passing along values, since they cannot be modified and equality always refers to equal values and not to equal identity. Let us have a look of how case classes can be declared and used.

result.msg:
5 Case Classes

In addition to classes and (companion) objects, Scala also provides so called case classes. These are special value classes which automatically provide lots of functionality. They are very useful for passing along values, since they cannot be modified and equality always refers to equal values and not to equal identity. Let us have a look of how case classes can be declared and used.

paragraphs.text:
// Case classes allow accessing the constructor parameters - they are provided as values
person.name

// But you cannot change a value - case classes are constant
person.name = "Bob"

%md
### Case Classes implement `copy` method
When you want to change a value of a case class, you actually have to make a copy. Fortunately this can be done very easily, since Scala provides a `copy` method which allows you to specify new values for zero, one or even multiple fields.

result.msg:
Case Classes implement copy method

When you want to change a value of a case class, you actually have to make a copy. Fortunately this can be done very easily, since Scala provides a copy method which allows you to specify new values for zero, one or even multiple fields.

paragraphs.text:
val p_1 = person.copy()
val p_2 = person.copy(age = 33)
val p_3 = person.copy(name="Bob", age = 33)

%md
### Case Classes override `equals` and `hashCode`

As already stated in the introduction of case classes, equality is not defined by identity, but really as identical values. This is provided by the automatic implementation of the `equals` and `hashCode` methods (which is available in every class).

result.msg:
Case Classes override equals and hashCode

As already stated in the introduction of case classes, equality is not defined by identity, but really as identical values. This is provided by the automatic implementation of the equals and hashCode methods (which is available in every class).

paragraphs.text:
// Instances of case classes are equal when their values are equal
person == Person("Alice", 23)

%md
### Case classes contain the `unapply` method

Case classes also implement the `unapply` method, which is used by Scala for deconstructing objects. This allows you to create magical code, that is easy to understand but at first glance a small miracle how it works.

result.msg:
Case classes contain the unapply method

Case classes also implement the unapply method, which is used by Scala for deconstructing objects. This allows you to create magical code, that is easy to understand but at first glance a small miracle how it works.

paragraphs.text:
// An existing Person instance can be deconstructed into its constructur arguments
val Person(name, age) = person

// This does not work with normal classes, if the unapply method is not implemented
val Location(x,y,name) = loc

%md
## 5.1 Pattern Matching

We already saw pattern matching in conjunction with simple flow control. But the real power of pattern matching is revealed with case classes.

result.msg:
5.1 Pattern Matching

We already saw pattern matching in conjunction with simple flow control. But the real power of pattern matching is revealed with case classes.

paragraphs.text: fn("Alice")
fn("Bob")
fn("Eve")

%md
### Pattern Matching with Case Classes

Now let us use case classes for pattern matching including deconstruction. This enables us to access the constructor variables of case classes inside the cases.

result.msg:
Pattern Matching with Case Classes

Now let us use case classes for pattern matching including deconstruction. This enables us to access the constructor variables of case classes inside the cases.

paragraphs.text: fn(Person("Alice", 23))
fn(Person("Bob", 41))
fn(Point(12,13))
fn("Hello World")

%md
Pattern matching also supports specifying additional conditions via `if` clauses in each case:

result.msg: Pattern matching also supports specifying additional conditions via if clauses in each case:

paragraphs.text: fn(Person("Alice",9))
fn(Person("Alice",20))
fn(Person("Alice",63))
